themes.label: Official Letters
themes.rationale: The inscription preserves a formal epistolary dossier, including a cover letter from a high official and a primary letter from King Antiochus III, utilizing standard Hellenistic diplomatic formulas.

themes.label: Edicts and Ordinances
themes.rationale: The text explicitly references a royal ordinance (prostagma) issued by the king regarding the appointment of a high priestess.
themes.quote: τοῦ γρα[φέντ]ος παρὰ τοῦ βασιλέως προστάγματος [περὶ] τὸ ἀποδεδέχθαι τῆς βασιλίσσης ἀρχιέρειαν

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The king expresses a specific intent to increase the honors (timas) bestowed upon Queen Laodice, framing the administrative act as an honorific gesture.
themes.quote: βουλόμενοι τῆς ἀδελφῆς βασιλίσσης Λαοδίκης [τ]ὰς τιμὰς ἐπὶ πλεῖον αὔξειν

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The text contains explicit instructions for the letters to be inscribed on a stone stele and displayed in a prominent location.
themes.quote: ἀναγραφέντα εἰς στήλην λιθίνην ἀνατεθῆι ἐν τῶι ἐπιφανεστάτωι τόπωι

themes.label: Other Stone
themes.rationale: The inscription identifies the material as stone (lithine), which is the standard medium for such royal decrees.

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The presence of numerous lacunae and restored text within brackets indicates that the physical carrier is not fully preserved.

persons.name: Laodice III
persons.role: Queen and sister of the King

rationale: This inscription, dated to 193 BC, is a vital document of Seleucid administration and religious policy. It records a dossier of correspondence: a cover letter from the official Anaximbrotus to Dionysius, and the primary letter from King Antiochus III to Anaximbrotus. The decree establishes a high priesthood for Queen Laodice III within the satrapy, appointing Berenice (daughter of Ptolemy, son of Lysimachus) to the position. The text details specific cultic honors, including the wearing of golden crowns with the Queen's image and the requirement that her name be included in legal contracts alongside the King's ancestors, illustrating the systematic integration of the royal cult into the civic and legal life of the empire.
